We propose a supervised learning approach to accurately detect whitecaps from airborne imagery obtained under a broad range of lighting conditions. This work aims to improve ocean and climate models. 

1. Motivation and Background

Exchanges between oceans and the atmosphere involve fifteen times as much carbon as human activities emit by burning fossil fuels, and are crucial in regulating the planet's temperature (Cavaleri et al., 2012). Understanding wave processes is key to better modeling our changing climate. Wave breaking governs many physical processes, including air-sea momentum, gas, and heat fluxes (Sullivan et al., 2007; Fairall et al., 2011). It also significantly increases albedo and aerosol concentrations, which are key variables in climate models (Lewis et al., 2004; Frouin et al., 2001). As waves break, they entrain air in the water column, leading to the formation of foam patches known as whitecaps. Analysis of wave breaking statistics typically involves analyzing the percentage of whitecap coverage of the sea surface (e.g., Callaghan & White, 2009). However, this approach does not provide information on the properties of breaking kinematics.

In (Phillips, 1985), wave breaking statistics were analyzed in terms of the distribution of the length of actively breaking waves per unit of sea surface area, denoted as (cb), where cb represents the speed of actively breaking waves. The main advantage of this approach is that moments of the (cb) distribution are related to many important physical quantities. Whitecap coverage is a function of the first moment of the distribution, and other properties, such as breaking-induced drift, momentum fluxes, and energy dissipation, can be derived from it.

Wave breaking is temporally and spatially variable, making it difficult to observe and characterize. While the Phillips (1985) theory was established decades ago, it is only in recent years that distributions were computed from high-resolution airborne imagery (Kleiss & Melville, 2010). Collected georeferenced images of the ocean surface are first gridded into a Cartesian coordinate system, and pixels with brightness above a certain threshold are classified as whitecaps (Kleiss & Melville, 2011). Whitecap kinematics are determined using Particle Image Velocimetry (PIV) and/or optical flow methods. However, this approach can be challenging due to difficulties in differentiating between sunglint and whitecaps, which can contaminate the results.

Expected Contributions

To overcome this issue and further our understanding of the role of wave breaking in air-sea interaction processes, we propose a data-driven approach that utilizes recent developments in deep learning techniques for computer vision. Sunglint and whitecaps have different spatial and temporal structures, which can be identified through neural network approaches. These techniques have been shown to outperform traditional approaches in other vision-based tasks (e.g., Grigorescu et al., 2020). Due to its ability to classify objects at pixel resolution with great accuracy, we propose the use of the UNet model (Ronneberger et al., 2015) in this work.

Data-Driven Approach for Filtering Sunglint

2. Observations

Aerial images of the sea surface obtained from several previous, ongoing, and planned airborne campaigns conducted at the Air-Sea Interaction Laboratory (SIO) will be used for training and validation of the model. Millions of sea surface images, obtained under a broad range of environmental conditions, were collected over the course of these expeditions. The database of aerial imagery will be georeferenced and gridded in a Cartesian coordinate system. The discretization step (pixel size) depends on the altitude of the aircraft. To ensure consistency, all images will be discretized with a resolution corresponding to the highest altitude flight under consideration (generally in the 0.1-0.5 meter range).
